question: Question_01
statement:
Consider the system of linear equations:

\begin{align*}
3x &\ +& 4y &\ +& 7z &\ &= 3\\
-9x &\ +& 6y &\ +& 9z &\ &= 3\\
45x &\ -& 12y &\ +& hz &\ &= k\end{align*} For which values of \emph{h} and \emph{k} does the system
have:

a) no solutions?

b) exactly one solution?

c) infinitely many solutions?
sols:
We can write this system in matrix form:

\begin{align*}\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 4 & 7 \\
-9 & 6 & 9 \\
45 & -12 & h
\end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array}{c}
x \\
y \\
z
\end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
3 \\
3 \\
k
\end{array} \right]\end{align*}

To know the number of solutions, we want to look at the row reduced form
of the augmented matrix.

First, perform the operations L\textsubscript{3} →
L\textsubscript{3}+5L\textsubscript{2} and L\textsubscript{2} →
L\textsubscript{2}-3L\textsubscript{1}

\begin{align*}\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3\\
-9 & 6 & 9 & 3\\
45 & -12 & h & k
\end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\
0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\
0 & 18 & 45 + h & 15+k
\end{array} \right]\end{align*} Then, perform L\textsubscript{3} →
L\textsubscript{3} - L\textsubscript{2}

\begin{align*}\sim \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
3 & 4 & 7 & 3 \\
0 & 18 & 30 & 12 \\
0 & 0 & 15+h & 3+k
\end{array} \right]\end{align*}

Noting that the first two rows of the matrix give a matrix of rank at
least 2, the number of solutions depend only on the last row. We read
the last row of this matrix and we obtain the equation

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
(15+h)z = 3+k\end{align*}

We can now read off the solutions from this equation base on whether or
not $15+h$ and $3+k$ are equal to zero.

a) No solution if $15+ h = 0, 3+k \ne 0$

b) One solution if $15+h \ne 0$

c) Infinite solution if $\displaystyle 15+ h = 0, 3+k = 0$

Notice that this convers all possible values for $\displaystyle 15+h$ and
$\displaystyle 3+k$.
hints:
Writing this system in matrix form, what will tell about the number of
solutions?

Pick carefully which row manipulations you will do, they will simplify
your calculations quite a bit.
